section.p: You can start getting familiar with the features by using the Interactive Example document:

li.p: Click Help->Examples , choose Quick Start Interactive Example .
Follow the example text.

section.p: You can see other examples in Help->Examples , or open them manually from: sernaInstallationPath/examples.
Try to create a new Docbook document:

li.p: Click Document->New , and in the New Document Dialog choose Docbook V4.2, article.
If you want to change the default encoding in your document click the Details... button, and change the value in the Encoding combo box.
Click OK .
The Enter Root Element Dialog will show up. Choose the root element (e.g. article).
The Document has been created! Now you can start editing. Usually authoring starts from inserting the title element: click Element->Insert... or Ctrl-Enter . Choose the title element.
You can insert title content either after the word Title: or in the gray area within the empty tag icon.

Now you can insert document content, for example a para tag. Put the cursor after title, e.g. after choose element. You can make sure the cursor is in the right position by looking at the status bar. The position should be listed as: /article[3], or /article[2], or /article/#choice[1].
Insert para with Ctrl-Enter , and enter some symbols into it.

Choose element means that the document schema requires an element in this position, but the content model allows for different elements, so you must choose one. If there's no such ambiguity, Serna automatically generates the required element. To resolve choose element, place the cursor on it and press Ctrl-Enter. Sometimes you may see several choose elements at once - in this case you may resolve them one-by-one in any order.

If you put the cursor at different positions in the document you may notice Context Hints, that for several seconds show elements adjacent to the cursor. Context Hints show the left, right, sibling, and parent elements when the cursor changes element position.

section.title: Abstract
section.p: In order to work with an XML document, you need to supply an XSL stylesheet which prescribes how to render the document. Providing an XML schema and a template for the document makes authoring even more convenient.
This article tells how to customize Serna to find the relevant XML metadata.
You may use the following metadata for XML document authoring:

li.p: Tells Serna how to represent your XML documents, therefore it is required for rendering. Usually it's better to have a specific stylesheet for your document type, but you can also use the generic default stylesheet, if you do not have a specific one.

Allows Serna to validate the content, automatically generate required elements, provide the user with a list of allowed elements in the current context and prevent insertion of invalid elements. An XML schema is not required, but is a great help for authoring.

note.p: If you have a DTD for your documents but do not have an XML schema, you can convert your DTD to a schema using Syntext Dtd2Xs.

li.p: Some XML documents require a DTD in order to be read. Although Serna does not use DTDs for validation during editing, DTDs are sometimes required by the XML parser, and may contain important internal or external entity definitions and #ID/#IDREF attribute definitions.

Document Templates provide a convenient way to associate all necessary XML metadata with the document. If you have a document template for your document, you can open the document in Serna with a single click. If you do not have a document template, you may need to specify paths to the XSL stylesheet, XML schema, etc. manually. See also on how to create a new document template.

section.p: You may change the default search paths to stylesheets, schemas and DTDs using Preferences->Search Path dialog.

To assign a path to the stylesheet, one must click the Advanced... button in the Open Document Dialog or New Document Dialog, and fill in the XSL Style text field (or press the Browse button next to this field).

You can specify an absolute path as well as a relative path to your stylesheet. A relative path may be specified with the $SERNA_DATA_DIR variable that points to the directory where Serna is installed. For example: $SERNA_DATA_DIR/plugins/MyCorporation/Memo.xsl

When loading a document that has nonempty DTD SYSID Serna tries to find and parse the DTD. To locate the DTD and XML entities Serna uses XML catalogs and/or DTD search paths (see on how to specify XML Catalogs and/or DTD search paths).

If you have an XML schema for your document, you may specify it by clicking the Advanced... button in the Open Document Dialog, or New Document Dialog, and filling in the Schema text field (or press the Browse button next to this field).

You can specify an absolute as well as relative path to your schema. A relative path can be specified with the $SERNA_DATA_DIR variable that points to the directory where Serna is installed. For example: $SERNA_DATA_DIR/plugins/MyCorporation/Memo.xsd.

In the New Document Dialog and Open with Template Dialog Serna provides a list of document templates found in the directory sernaInstallPath/xml/templates and the directories sernaInstallPath/plugins/*. The document templates have *.sdt paths.
To create a new document click New Document (menu or button). In the New Document Dialog you have the option of specifying additional XML meta-information for your document depending on your needs.

note.p: To specify encoding for your document click the Advanced... button and choose the appropriate value in the Encoding pull-down field.

li.p: If you wish to create an XML document that has no DTD, no defined schema or special stylesheet you merely click OK . Serna will ask you for the root element for your document.

li.b: Creating a document from a template (e.g. Docbook document)
li.p: For certain types of XML files you may have predefined Document Templates, e.g for Docbook documents. To create such documents in the New Document Dialog you merely choose the name of the appropriate template, and then click OK . (E.g. choose: Docbook V4.2 - Book to create a Docbook with book book root element).
If the document template contains a root element Serna will not ask for it.

note.p: See on how to create custom document templates for your XML documents.
If you want to change some values provided by template you can edit them clicking Advanced... button before clicking OK .

li.p: If you want to create an XML document for which you have some combination of a DTD, schema, or stylesheet but do not have a Document Template you should provide the path to these files manually. For this click the Advanced... button and fill in the appropriate values.

section.p:
To open an existing document, click the Open Document button or choose the Document Open... menu item. Serna does its best to determine the document type and open the document.
All DITA documents are opened by default with the DITA V1.1 template. To open a DITA V1.0 document with the DITA V1.0 template, choose Document Open with Template , browse for the document in the Open Document with Template Dialog, and then select the template in the Choose Document Template Dialog.
If it can't determine the file type, Serna will tell you that no document template matched, and give you the following options:

li.p: If you are opening a document type unknown to Serna, then click the Default icon. Serna will open the document with the default template.
Serna will bring up the Document Templates Dialog. If, for example, you are opening an XHTML document, double-click the XHTML icon. Serna will open your document with that template.

topic.title: Opening an Existing Document with Manually Specified Parameters

section.p: If you open a document with the Open... command, Serna tries to provide you with stylesheet, schema, and encoding that best matches your document (it uses Document Templates, see ).
To manually specify the schema, stylesheet, encoding or template:

li.p: Use the Open with Template... command (see )
Select the file and hit OK
Serna will then provide the Document Template Dialog. You can either choose a template, or click the Details... button and manually specify the path for the schema, stylesheet, and encoding

note.p: See on how to create custom document templates for your XML documents.

section.p: There are two major modes for editing documents: WYSIWYG mode and Tag mode. The former is very close to a conventional word processor, while the latter is convenient for editing script-like documents, where seeing XML tags is helpful.
XSL stylesheets for editing are supposed to do their best to represent the document conveniently in WYSIWYG mode, but sometimes the author may need to switch to Tag mode.
To switch modes, either select View->Show/Hide Markup or click the Show/Hide Markup button on the status bar.

note.p: There is also Text Mode for plain text editing. This mode is convenient for specific XML source code editing (e.g. manually fixing invalid XML documents). It is recommended that users do not do any authoring in Text Mode.
See also .

section.p: Knowing Serna selection and navigation functionality makes authoring very easy and productive.
In balancing mode selection takes all element content automatically when the cursor crosses an element border. In non-balancing selection mode you can do precise selection across elements.
To switch between balancing and non-balancing modes use the Edit->Balance Selection command.

note.p: When you want to select several list items you can start the selection from the middle of the first list item and finish in the middle of the last item. You do not need to do any precise clicks.

section.p: To select an element, triple click the element, or click the element and use Ctrl+Alt+Up key combination.

It is very easy to select elements with the Parent Selection function. Put the cursor somewhere in the element you want to select and hit Ctrl+Alt+Up to select the element. Then using the Edit->Select Parent or Edit->Deselect Parent commands you can select (or deselect) the upper ancestor of the selected element.

note.p: Suppose you want to copy a para element with all its content. All you need to is put the cursor somewhere in the element and do Ctrl-Alt-Up (or Ctrl-Alt-Down , if you selected more than needed) from one to several times to select the para. Then simply copy the selection with Ctrl-C !

section.p: To select the element content, for example, text within a para element, choose Edit Select Content ( Ctrl Alt S ).
To navigate skipping the elements you will need the Next/Previous Element and Element Start/End commands. These commands are especially handy when navigating through lists or table cells.

note.p: The most convenient way to navigate in a list is by using the Ctrl-Up / Ctrl-Down hot keys.

section.p: A Liquid Dialog Box is one that can appear in three modes:

li.p: As a regular non-modal dialog
As a docked pane
In a short version, as a docked toolbar (top-docked)

section.p: To change the docking, right-click on the dialog pane and choose the docking mode:
Currently there are three liquid dialogs: Insert Element Dialog, Element Attributes Dialog, and Find&Replace Dialog. For example, here are the three appearances of the Element Attributes Dialog:
There are several ways to collapse and expand:

li.p: View Collapse Element collapses either the current element or the parent of the current element if there is a folding list for the given document type (see below).
View Collapse Element also collapses the selected elements.
View Collapse parent element name collapses an ancestor of the currently selected element.

section.p: The following are ways to expand elements:

li.p: View Expand expands the current collapsed element (but not its children if some are collapsed).
View Expand Subtree expands the current element, and all its children.
View Expand All expands all the collapsed elements in the document.

section.p: Suppose you frequently collapse chapters and sections, but never para's. If you want to quickly collapse the current section without moving the cursor from the current para, you can narrow the list of collapsible elements. (For details see folding-list element in ). If there is a Folding List for your document, then collapsing will collapse the closest parent element that is mentioned in the list.

Serna allows you to work with very large documents. When opening a document Serna estimates the number of pages based on the number of elements in the document. If the estimation exceeds the large document size, the document may be opened collapsed.
Serna considers the document large if the estimation exceeds the large document size in Tools Preferences Folding . The default is 50 pages.

Serna estimates the document size from an assumption of how many elements form a page. The default is 30. It is possible to change the default for a particular type of document (e.g. Docbook). See details on elems-per-page in .
When opening a large document Serna may: ask if you want to collapse document elements; always collapse; or never collapse. See Tools Preferences Folding .
Copy and Paste actually copy and paste XML structures. If you copy from Serna to another application you paste XML source.

If you need to copy from Serna what you literally see (without XML tags), use Copy as Text. If you want to copy from Serna to Serna without XML tags, then use either the Copy as Text or Paste as Text command.

topic.title: How to Edit Document XML Source?

section.p: It is possible to edit the source of XML document in Serna, i.e. edit document as text. There are two possible approaches:

li.p: Go to Help Switch to Text Mode to edit your whole document as XML source.
Note, this mode is not recommended for general user, and is intended mostly for fixing XML syntax errors. Use this mode only if you know what you are doing.
You can edit the source of only a part of the XML document. For this select the portion you wish to edit, and select Edit Edit Selection as Text , Edit Selection as Text Dialog will appear.
If you make a syntactic error while editing the selected portion, Serna will signal error and refuse to accept the changes you have made.

section.p: If the document was opened or created with an XML schema then it is dynamically validated, or validated on-the-fly. That means Serna helps the user by providing:

li.p: lists of available elements and attributes for element insertion
reports on invalid content creation (elements, attributes, text)
automatic creation of unambiguously required elements (fix-up functionality)
choose element boxes, that indicate that at this position an element is required, but the user must manually choose the required element from a list

section.p: To change validation mode use: Edit->Validation .
There are three validation modes:

li.p: No validation is performed.
Document is dynamically validated, but user may create invalid content (element, attributes, etc). Serna only signals errors in a Message Window.
Document is dynamically validated, and Serna does not allow user to create invalid elements. If you attempt to create invalid content Serna undoes the operation.

note.p: Strict validation mode is recommended for inexperienced XML document writers.

You see one more Choose element. Either click it or press Ctrl Alt Enter .

section.title: Element Splitting and Joining

li.p: Type "Orange" in the para. Press Enter. The para will be split (a new para will be inserted).
Do not type anything in the new para. Press Enter immediately again. This will split the first listitem.

note.p: To split the current element, press Enter, or choose Element -> Split Element , or click the Split Element button on the toolbar.

li.p: Type "Lemon" in the para. Press Enter twice to split the listitem.
Type "Apple" in the para. Press Enter twice to split the listitem.

Choose Element -> Join Elements .

note.p: To join two elements of the same type going in a row, select the latter element and choose Element -> Join Elements or click the Join Elements button on the toolbar.

section.title: Element Renaming
section.p:
Let's rename the itemizedlist element:
The cursor is in the para. Press Ctrl UpArrow twice to move from the para element to the itemizedlist element.

Let's turn our itemizedlist into orderedlist. Type "or" and the orderedlist will be offered. Press Enter or click the Rename button.
In the dialogs, the elements are in alphabetical order. If you know exactly which element you need, you can start typing its name and it will be offered automatically.

section.title: Wrapping in Element
section.p: Above, we first inserted an element and then created its content. However, you can first create some content and then wrap the content in an element.
Let's wrap the word "Lime" in the emphasis element:

li.p: Select the word "Lime". When you make a selection, the Insert Element Dialog is replaced with the Wrap Into Element Dialog.
Press Ctrl Enter to move the focus to the Wrap Into Element Dialog.

In the Attributes Dialog, click the
Add Attribute

Type the underline value and press Enter.

li.p: Put the cursor in the emphasis element.
Press Ctrl U .

note.p: To untag an element, put the cursor in the element and press Ctrl U or choose Element -> Untag Element .

li.p: Put the cursor in the text of the item.
Press Ctrl Alt UpArrow twice to select the listitem element.
Press the Delete key. The "Apple" listitem will be deleted.

note.p: To delete a selected element, press the Delete key or Backspace key.

li.p:

Press the Delete key.

Press Ctrl Z to undo the deletion operation.

Let's learn to copy/cut/paste elements:
Triple click the "Orange" text to select the para.

Press Ctrl X to cut the para.

li.p: Triple click the "Lemon" text to select the para.
Press Ctrl Alt C to copy just the text of the selection.
Put the cursor after the "Lemon" text and press Ctrl V to paste the copied text.

Select the second word "Lemon".
Drag the selection over the document.
Where the dropping of the current selection is not allowed, you see a crossed circle.
Where the dropping of the current selection is allowed, you see the Insert Element icon.

topic.title: Working with Elements and Attributes in ContentMap

section.p: Above, we worked with elements in the Editing Window. Actually, you can perform manipulations with elements in the ContentMap as well.
The ContentMap tree shows the elements of the document as well as empty branches where you can insert, paste and drop elements.

Let's perform some basic manipulations with elements in the ContentMap:
Element Insertion
Click the empty branch - the end of the para element. Let's insert a new element there.
Press Ctrl Enter to call the Insert Element Dialog.
In the Insert Element Dialog, select the ulink element.
In the Required Attributes Dialog, enter the value of the url attribute. Click OK .
The ulink element is inserted.
Type the content of the ulink.
Element Renaming
Click the orderedlist element in the ContentMap. Let's rename it.
Press Ctrl R to call the Rename Element Dialog.
In the Rename Element Dialog, select the itemizedlist element.
The orderedlist is renamed to itemizedlist.
Drag&Drop
Click the first listitem in the ContentMap.
Drag the listitem over the tree structure.
You see a crossed circle where the dropping of the listitem is not allowed and a pointer cursor with the tag of the listitem where it is allowed.
Drop the listitem after the last listitem. Now the "Orange" listitem is the last.

You can also perform other operations with elements in the ContentMap, which is analogous to performing the same operations in the Editing Window in most cases.
To split an element, click it and choose Element -> Split Element , or click the Split Element button on the toolbar. Note that the Enter key won't work to split elements in the ContentMap and consequently the advanced split won't work.
To join two elements of the same type going in a row, select the latter element and choose Element -> Join Elements or click the Join Elements button on the toolbar.
To wrap an element in another element, select the element and press Ctrl Enter or Ctrl T , or choose Element- > Tag Region to call the Wrap Into Element Dialog.
To untag an element, click it and press Ctrl U or choose Element -> Untag Element .
To edit attributes of an element, click the element and press Alt Enter , or choose Element -> Element Attributes , or click the Element Attributes button on the toolbar.
If you point the cursor over an element in the ContentMap, you'll see a hint with its attributes.
To delete an element in the ContentMap, click either it or the empty branch before the element and press the Delete key, or click the empty branch after the element and press the Backspace key.
To cut/copy an element in the ContentMap, select the element and press Ctrl X / Ctrl C . To copy just the text of the selection, press Ctrl Alt C .
To paste an element, press Ctrl V . To paste an element as text, press Ctrl Alt V .

Editing in Serna is pretty easy without displaying the tags. You've learnt to manipulate elements in Serna in the pure WYSIWYG mode. If you wish, you can switch to the Markup mode to see the markup tags:
Choose View -> Show Markup .
The markup will be displayed.
Choose View -> Hide Markup to return to the pure WYSIWYG mode.

section.title: Abstract
section.p: Custom Content is a pre-defined content portion (template) that can be inserted into your document through an associated button or a hot key.
To learn more about Custom Content, see , , , and .
For instructions on how to create a Custom Content template, see or proceed to the quick start example :
See example Creating a Command for emphasis Element Insertion.

example.title: Creating a Command for emphasis Element Insertion
example.p: Suppose you want to create a button that will insert emphasis elements, or wrap the selected content into the emphasis element. Do the following:

li.p: Insert the emphasis element to any valid place in your document.
Select this element.
Click Edit Custom Content New Custom Content .
The Custom Content Dialog will appear with the Content edit box containing: <emphasis role="bold"/>
Hit OK: a new Insert emphasis button will show up on the Custom Content Toolbar.

example.p: Now, if you hit this button the emphasis element will be inserted. If you select some content and hit this button, then the selected content will be wrapped into the emphasis element.

note.p: By default, every change made to the Serna GUI is not permanent: you should save it before you close the document. If you forgot to save changes, open the document from the recent file list: the GUI with your changes will be restored. For instructions on how to save the GUI view, see .

section.p: The Custom Content Dialog allows you to create a command that inserts a pre-defined content template into your document (e.g bold, graphic, etc). To learn more about Custom Content, see . For instructions on how to create Custom Content, see .
For a new custom content template there are automatically assigned default values that the user may modify when creating a new template:

li.p: Unique identifier for the new custom content template.
Human-readable inscription.
Icon for the button which inserts this custom content template.
The hot key associated with this custom content template. To assign the hot key, just put the cursor into this edit box and hit the key combination.

The Content edit box provides the XML content which will be inserted if the result of XSLT match expression in the If matches edit box evaluates to true at the current cursor position. Empty Context always evaluates to true, and the first content with matched context expression is applied.

The Node edit box and Position combo-box define the position where the inserted template should go relatively to the current cursor position. If you want to insert a custom content into the current cursor position, leave the Node edit box empty. Otherwise, the Node edit box must contain an XPath expression which returns a node-set from which the first node will be used to determine the insert position (see also ). If the returned node-set is empty, then the insert operation is not performed, and the current content template alternative is considered as not matched even if the If matches match expression evaluates to true.
The Add and Remove buttons allow you to create/delete multiple context-sensitive custom content templates (see also ).

note.p: By default, every change made to the Serna GUI is not permanent: you should save it before you close the document. If you forgot to save changes, open the document from the recent file list: the GUI with your changes will be restored. For instructions on how to save the GUI view, see .

section.p: The Edit Custom Content Dialog allows you to remove, modify and save existing custom content insertion commands.
To modify the selected command, click the Edit... button (See for more details).

note.p: By default, every change made to the Serna GUI is not saved for the document or template: you should save it before you close the document. If you forgot to save changes then open the document from the recent file list: the GUI with your changes will be restored. For instructions on how to save the GUI view, see .

section.p: Usually you create a template for your content insertion command by selecting some content and choosing Edit Custom Content New Custom Content (or hitting the Create New Custom Content button on the custom content toolbar). If you hit OK in the Custom Content Dialog, then the template, command, and button for the template insertion become available for the currently edited document. For more details on the dialog, see .

If you create a template for a custom content as is, by just taking it from the document, then upon insertion the cursor (and selected content, if there is a selection) will appear within the first element of the template, if any.
You may adjust the custom content template with the Custom Content Dialog's Content edit box:

li.p: The $(cursor) keyword within your template indicates that the cursor and/or wrapped content will go into this position.
For example, the custom content template:
applied to the selected portion: some words will produce:
The $(attribute) keyword within the attribute value will invoke the Attributes Dialog when inserting the custom content.
For example, the template:

will invoke the Element Attributes Dialog for the id attribute, and insert the selected content (if any) instead of $(cursor). Note that the following form of the keyword: $(attribute caption="My caption") will change the caption of the Element Attributes Dialog to My caption.

When inserting certain elements (like graphics), it is very convenient to call a file browser. This is possible with the keyword file. For example: $(file caption="My caption" filter="Images (*.gif *.jpg);; All files (*)"). Note that caption provides a caption for the file browser, and filter provides the filters for the file list:
li.codeblock: <graphic fileref="$(file caption='Choose Image' filter='Image files (*.gif *.jpg);;All files (*)')"/>
li.p: will call a file browser, and insert a graphic with the fileref attribute with the relative file path to the image.
Custom Content can automatically generate unique IDs which consist of the element name and a unique sequence number:
will insert <section id="section_1"> and so on.
It is also possible to specify custom ID format for the Custom Content:
This example will use timestamp-based ID plus optional sequence number. Format is determined by the percent sign with a single format letter; other symbols are copied as-is.
The default format string (when format string is not specified) is "%q_%n". All possible format sequences are described below.
Local name of the element.
Qualified name (QName) of the element.
Timestamp presented as eight hexadecimal digits.
Mangled current file name.
Current entity name, if any.
Explicit sequence number; at least one digit.

Implicit sequence number which is added only when the ID string generated without this number is not unique. If the %n is not specified in the format string, it is implicitly assumed to be at the end of the format string.

If, for some reason, you want to insert the above-mentioned keywords to your templates but do not want them to be substituted, escape them with the double $ sign. For example, $$(cursor)will appear in your text literally as $(cursor), and will not be replaced.

topic.title: Context Sensitivity and Insertion Position of Custom Content

body.section:
Suppose you want to insert images by means of custom content. Let's suggest that your schema requires the inlinegraphic element for an image within text, while when in the section element, it requires the figure element with a child called graphic.
It is possible to specify several templates for different contexts of your document. The context is specified as XSLT Match Pattern in the If matches edit box. For each additional context you must create a separate tab in the Custom Content Dialog, specify a specific context match expression, and the content template for this content.
By default the content template will be inserted into the current cursor position. However, it may be inserted into another position relative to the current cursor position. This different position may be specified with XPath Expression in the Node: text box and the Position: combo-box. See example Creating a Context-Sensitive Image Insertion Command.
You can specify any number of alternative content templates. Every context, starting from the first, is tested against the Context match expression. If the expression evaluates to true in the current context, or if there is no match expression ( If matches field is empty), then the Content will be inserted. See example Inserting Custom Content to a Position that is Different from the Current Cursor Position.

example.title: Creating a Context-Sensitive Image Insertion Command
example.p: For creating a custom content described in the first paragraph of this section, do the following:

li.p: Choose Edit Custom Content New Custom Content .
In the Custom Content Dialog, specify:
Name: myInsertGraphic (this will identify the new command).
Inscription: Insert Graphic (this will be the human-readable inscription for the command).
Icon: browse for your favourite icon.
Hot key: hit some key combination when the cursor is in this window. For example: Ctrl-Alt-M.

note.p: You may leave the above-mentioned properties as they are provided by default.

li.p: In the Content edit box, enter:
li.codeblock: <inlinegraphic fileref="$(file caption='Choose Image' filter='Image files (*.gif *.jpg);;All files (*)')"/>

li.p: In the If matches edit box, enter: text()

This means that if the match expression text() returns true for the current context (i.e. when the cursor is in the text), then the template from Content will be inserted. The Custom Content Dialog should look like this:

fig.title: First Context for a Custom Content

li.p: Now, click the Add button: this will add a new context tab for the current content command.
In the new tab, specify for Content :
In the new tab, specify for Context :
These match expressions will return true if the cursor is immediately within the section or chapter elements. The Custom Content Dialog should look like this:

fig.title: Second Context for a Custom Content

example.title: Inserting Custom Content to a Position that is Different from the Current Cursor Position
example.p: Sometimes you need to insert a content into a position which is different from the current cursor position. For example, usually you want to insert a new paragraph below the current paragraph, despite the fact that the cursor may be currently located within text or an emphasis element within the paragraph.
For this case you should specify the relative position where the inserted content should go. See the figure below:
In this example, the Position is after , and the Node is

This means that the para will be inserted not into the current cursor position, but after "the first para node among all the ancestors of the current node, including the node itself". For example, if the cursor is within an emphasis of a para, the para will be found, and after it the new para will be inserted.

section.p: Sometimes the current context node information is not enough to achieve the exact positioning of Custom Content. For example, when the cursor stands between two emphasis elements in a para, or when the cursor is just before the first para, or just after the last para, the context node is still the same, i.e. para.
To bypass this limitation Custom Content adds two custom functions which can be used in XSLT patterns and XPath position expressions.

li.p: Returns all sibling nodes to the right of the cursor position. If the cursor stands currently in text position, this function will return all the sibling nodes subsequent to the current text node.
Returns all sibling nodes to the left of the cursor position. If the cursor stands currently in text position, this function will return all the sibling nodes previous to the current text node.

section.p: For example, if you specify "Insert Before" and XPath location expression cc:nodes-after()[self::emphasis][2], Custom Content will try to insert your content just before the second emphasis to the right of the current position.

To create a new custom content template, take the steps below. The example shows the general approach to insertion of a simple template consisting of a single element. You can also create a template with an arbitrary structure (see ).
Create an element in the current document. The element will form your Custom Content template structure.
To select the element, right-click on it and choose Select Parent . Selecting a portion, you designate the template content for the Custom Content.
Go to Edit -> Custom Content -> New Custom Content or click the Create New Custom Content button on the toolbar.
In the Custom Content Dialog, specify Name , Inscription , Icon and Hotkey for the action or leave them as default.
If needed, adjust the content in the Content edit box.
If needed, enter the Node and select the Position .
If needed, make the custom content context-sensitive:
In the Content edit box, enter the content.
In the If matches edit box, specify context conditions for the content.
If needed, enter the Node and select the Position .
To specify more context-sensitive content templates, click the Add button.
Click OK .

Serna includes ability to display help information for elements and attributes for the current Schema. To enable element help, document template must specify the path to the element help file (see the Developer's Guide for more details about document templates and element help file format).
When Serna element help is enabled, it can be invoked in several ways:

li.p: When mouse pointer is moved over the element list, tooltip with the short help is shown. Pressing ' Element Help ' button shows full help page for the currently selected element, if available.

When mouse pointer is moved over some cell in the attributes dialog or over the attribute list in combo-box (when inserting a new attribute), the short help is shown as a tooltip. Pressing ' Element Help' button shows full help page for the currently selected attribute, if available.
Pressing F11 (or invoking Help -> Element Help ) shows the full help page for the element in the current cursor position.

section.p: If you would like to create Element Help to your own document types (XML schema), please see Developer's Guide "Element Help Definition".
With Redlining author may mark and annotate document portion to indicate to another author that the portion should be removed, added or worked on.

li.p: To indicate that the selected document portion should be added click Redlining Redline As Inserted... An Redline As Inserted Dialog will show up, where user may type the annotation.
The portion will be marked green and underlined.
To indicate that the selected document portion should be removed click Redlining Redline As Deleted... An Redline As Deleted Dialog will show up, where user may type the comment for the redlining.
The portion will be marked red and strike-through.
To comment the selected document portion click Redlining Redline As Commented... An Redline As Commented Dialog will show up, where user may type the comment.
The selected portion will be marked with yellow.

note.p: If you usually do not need to annotate the redlining, unset Redlining Ask for Annotation .

section.p: To see the comments on redlined portions, or to change the comments click Redlining Edit Redlining... The Edit Redlining Dialog will appear. You can change the type of redlining, and the comment for the redlining.

If you have many redlinings in your document you may want to navigate on redlining. For this click Redlining Find Previous Redlining... or Redlining Find Next Redlining... Serna will find the redlined portion adjacent to the cursor.
You now can reject redlining, which means that redlining marks will be removed and "inserted" redlining will disappear, and "deleted" redlining will stay.
You can also accept redlining, which means that redlining marks will be removed and "inserted" redlining will stay, and "deleted" redlining will disappear.

note.p: If you need to automatically move to the next redlining after review check Redlining Move After Review.

section.p: XInclude is a mechanism that allows you to aggregate several standalone XML documents into your document. In general XInclude is very similar to external entities , but there are two major differences:

li.p: External entities are not self-contained. Within an external entity it is not possible to define DOCTYPE as well as local internal or external entities.
External entities are always included as a whole. In contrast, when xincluding you may merge only a portion of the xincluded document (referenced by XPointer).

section.p: See for more details on the XInclude standard support.
To xinclude a document:

li.p: Place a cursor in the location where you would like to xinclude another document
Choose Entity XInclude XML File...

note.p: You can also include a document "as text". For this use Entity XInclude Text File... command.

li.p: Browse for the document you wish to xinclude. Serna will read it with its DTD and/or XML Schema in order to determine the IDs available in the document
In the XInclude XML File Dialog choose either the ID of the element you wish to insert into your document or "Insert Whole Document"
You may also change/add XInclude attributes. Hit Attributes... button for the XInclude Attributes Dialog.
Click OK . The xincluded document will show up in xinclude brackets.

topic.title: How to Make a Part of My Document Xincluded?

section.p: It is also possible to make a portion of your document a separate Xincluded document. For this:

li.p: Select the portion you want to convert to Xincluded document.

note.p: Note that only the selection that contains single element (that possibly has children or text) or text-only selections are convertible to xincluded portions.

li.p: Click Edit Convert to XInclude .
In the Convert to XInclude Dialog choose the file name for new xincluded document.
You may also change/add XInclude attributes. Hit Attributes... button for the XInclude Attributes Dialog.
Click OK . The xincluded document will show up in xinclude brackets.

topic.title: How to Find out Why My XInclude Failed?

section.p: If you see black empty xinclude brackets or you see a fallback element instead of your xincluded document, it means that for some reason Serna could not locate the file you wanted to xinclude. To find out the reason, put a cursor in the brackets and select Entity Current XInclude Status... . Detailed status and error report will be shown.

topic.title: How to Find out the Location of My XInclude?

section.p: Put a cursor within the XInclude brackets. Select Entity Current XInclude Status... The Current XInclude Status Dialog will show the document href and xpointer, and the list of errors if the fragment could not be properly inserted.
WebDAV (aka DAV) stands for "Web-based Distributed Authoring and Versioning". This functionality allows you to edit and save documents shared with other people on a DAV-enabled server.
See for more details on the WebDAV standard support.
With Serna you can:

li.p: Open and edit documents from the DAV server
Save a document to DAV server
XInclude portions of the document from the DAV server
Reference external entities from the DAV server
Reference other resources (such as images) from the DAV or HTTP server

topic.title: How to Open a Document on WebDAV Server?

li.p: There are three ways to open a document from WebDAV server:
This is the usual way to open the document from WebDAV location. Select Document WebDAV Open...
This is useful when you want to open text file or broken XML document from WebDAV location. Select Document WebDAV Open as Plain Text...

li.b: Open XML document with a specific template
li.p: Sometimes Serna is unable to guess proper document template, or you may want to open the document with a specific template. In this case Select Document WebDAV Open with Template...
The WebDAV Open Document Dialog will show up. In the editbox Collection URL.. specify the URL with the path where the document resides and hit Enter.

note.p: Make sure you specify the path where the document resides, but not the document URL. E.g. if the document URL is http://myserver:8080/dav/project/1.xml, then specify: http://myserver:8080/dav/project/

li.p: The files residing in the DAV directory will then be shown.
In the editbox filename or in the file browser select the file to open. Click OK.

topic.title: How to Save Document to a WebDAV Server

li.p: Select Document WebDAV Save As...
The WebDAV Save As Dialog will show up. In the editbox Collection URL.. specify the URL with the path where the document resides and hit Enter.

note.p: Make sure you specify the path where the document resides, but not the document URL. E.g. if the document URL is http://myserver:8080/dav/project/1.xml, then specify: http://myserver:8080/dav/project/

li.p: The files residing in the DAV directory will then be shown.
In the editbox filename or in the file browser select the file to open. Click OK.

section.p: The dialog Document WebDAV Properties... (WebDAV Properties Dialog) allows you to specify:

li.p: Proxy for WebDAV connections
WebDAV connection timeout
Document locking policy:

In this mode Serna does strict locking, and acquires write lock for the document itself and all entities/xincludes used in the document. If Serna is unable to acquire write lock, it makes corresponding portions of document read-only.
In this mode Serna just checks for existence of locks, and makes certain document entities read-only if valid locks are found for them.
Serna does not do locking and does not check for any locks.

section.p: There are three major aspects of whitespace handling in the editor: reading document, saving document, and editing.

li.p: White-spaces are preserved or stripped according to stylesheet xsl:strip-space, xsl:preserve-space top-level instructions and to xml:space attributes in the particular document, exactly following the procedure specified in XSLT 1.0 standard. By default white-spaces are preserved. If the document is opened with a DTD, then element-only content is also whitespace stripped.
Serna does its best to save the document pretty-indented, at the same time obeying whitespace handling rules. The following rules apply:
If stylesheet specifies that white-spaces are preserved for an element, then the white-spaces are preserved for that element, and the element content is not indented.
If the element is not specified in the stylesheet as whitespace-preserved, then the element content is pretty-indented.

Ability to insert white-spaces during editing is controlled by the XSL-FO properties white-space-treatment, white-space-collapse, linefeed-treatment in the stylesheet. If the attributes are set to: preserve, false, and preserve respectively then it becomes possible for a user to insert the white-spaces and new lines as in a conventional word editor.
By default consecutive white-spaces are simplified to a single whitespace.

topic.title: Migrating Customizations from One Serna Version to Another

section.p: Starting from version 3.0 it's no longer needed to uninstall old version of Serna before installing newer versions. Different versions can be installed on single computer at the same time.
Note, that user settings and packages (plugins, stylesheets, etc) set in one version will not be visible in another.

li.b: Migrating your own Custom Content, Interface Customizations, XSLT Parameter Sets
li.p: If you created the above-mentioned customizations as a user (they were not set by packages or plugins) you should manually copy corresponding files and directories to new configuration directory.

Pre-3.0 versions of Serna have .serna2 subdirectory in C:\Documents and Settings\LOGIN\ on Windows (and $HOME/ on Linux and Mac OS X) as its configuration directory. Versions of Serna starting from 3.0 have .serna-<VERSION-ID> subdirectory as corresponding configuration directory, where <VERSION-ID> is a string obtained by concatenating first two version numbers with a dot in between (for example: 3.3)

Example: in order to migrate custom content information, user interface customizations and XSLT parameter sets from version 3.0 to 3.1, you should copy all files with extensions .scc .sui, and .xsltp from the configuration directory .serna-3.0 to .serna-3.1.

li.b: Migrating your own Plugins and Document Type Packages (DTD, Schemas, Templates and Stylesheets)
li.p: Each new version of Serna that has difference in first or second version number (e.g. 3.1, 3.2 and 4.3 have this difference) is installed by default to version specific installation directory (C:\Program Files\Syntext\Serna-<VERSION-ID> on Windows, /usr/local/serna-<VERSION-ID> on Linux and /Applications/Syntext Serna <VERSION-ID> on Mac OS X.

Therefore the plugins and Document Type Packages (i.e. customizations that contain document templates, DTDs, schemas and stylesheets) that are visible in one version is not visible in another. In order to migrate them to the newly installed version you should manually copy them from old version directory (e.g /usr/local/serna-3.0) to its corresponding subdirectory in new one (e.g /usr/local/serna-3.1).

In order to migrate your own custom speller dictionary to the new version copy all files *.pws from old Serna user configuration directory to the new configuration directory. For example in order to migrate from version 2.X to 3.0 copy all files *.pws from .serna2 directory to .serna-3.0 directory.

section.p: The Publish Dialog allows you to create a presentation of your XML file for different media (e.g. HTML, PDF, etc.) by calling an external application. See in the Developer's Guide for details.
Choose the publishing output from the Publishing output drop-down list. This will change the output generation parameters in the text box below. You can also change the parameters manually.

To initiate generation, click the Generate... button. Note that the generation of the output will be performed in the directory where the file is residing. This means you must have write permissions for the directory.

When the output is generated, you can click the View... button to call the external viewer. To choose the viewer for a particular file type (extension), set the application in Tools Preferences Applications .

section.p: ContentMap is a powerful replacement for older TOC window. It shows document in tree-like manner and provides precise and easy navigation through the document. ContentMap has following benefits:

li.p: Shows elements, processing-instructions, comments, entities, and XIncludes;
Allows to place cursor on elements and between elements;
Provides several profiled views of the document;
Allows Drag`and`Drop editing, both within ContentMap and between ContentMap and editing window;
ContentMap is governed by simpler style language;

section.p: ContentMap shows document elements, structural nodes (entity and XInclude borders), PIs and comments, and also positions between them. When you move mouse over ContentMap items they are highlighted to better demonstrate position in the document tree. Tooltips are popped up showing element attributes and item`s text.
Use following keys to browse the ContentMap:

li.p: Make the first item (root element) current and visible.
Make the last item current and visible.
Make the item above the top visible item current and visible.
Make the item below the bottom visible item current and visible.
Make the item above the current item current and visible.
Make the item below the current item current and visible.

If the current item is closed (+ icon) or has no children, make its parent item current and visible. If the current item is open (- icon) close it, i.e. hide its children. Exception: if the current item is the first item and is closed and the horizontal scrollbar is offset to the right the list view will be scrolled left.

If the current item is closed (+ icon) and has children, the item is opened. If the current item is opened (- icon) and has children the item's first child is made current and visible. If the current item has no children the list view is scrolled right.

section.p: To change cursor position do either:

li.p: Press Enter to make current ContentMap item the current cursor position.
Left mouse click on ContentMap item to make it the current cursor position.

note.p: Cursor position may not present in editing view in case of stylesheet bug. In this case real position is shown in status bar and blinking cursor disappears. This although allows you to author document as usual.
To easily switch cursor between ContentMap and editing window use F3 hot key.

section.p: By default input focus is kept in ContentMap when you navigate there. If you want focus to be transferred to editing window each time Enter pressed or mouse clicked in ContentMap then toggle ON button at the top of ContentMap.

To select a whole item, click the item and press the Space key or do Ctrl+left-mouse-click on the item:
If this item is an element, the whole element with its content will be selected.
If this item is ExternalEntity, InternalEntity, XInclude then the whole entity or XIncluded fragment will be selected.
To select the content (text) of an item only, click the item and use Ctrl+Alt+S key combination.

To select a portion of the document, click the item to start the selection from and holding down the Shift key click the item to end the selection with, or click the item to start the selection from and use Shift+UpArrow/DownArrow key combination.
To select/unselect the parent element, click the item and use Ctrl+Alt+UpArrow/DownArrow key combination.
To remove element in ContentMap press Delete on an item. If this item is ExternalEntity, InternalEntity, XInclude then the whole entity or XIncluded fragment will be removed.
When a cursor is between ContentMap items it is possible to remove siblings:

li.p: Press Delete to remove next sibling ContentMap item. If next sibling item is ExternalEntity, InternalEntity, XInclude then the whole entity or XIncluded fragments removed.
Press Backspace to remove previous sibling ContentMap item. If previous sibling item is ExternalEntity, InternalEntity, XInclude then the whole entity or XIncluded fragment is removed.

section.p: Drag-and-Drop editing is available in ContentMap. It is possible to drag item or selection from ContentMap and:

li.p: drop it into ContentMap to the different location
drop it into editing window

section.p: It is also possible to drag document selection from editing window and drop it into ContentMap.

note.p: Serna may refuse a drop in a specific position if it is not allowed by the XML schema constraint.
If you drop in on the ContentMap item then the content is dropped at the beginning of this element (before its content if any).

section.p: To copy elements and selections using drag-and-drop hold CTRL button while dragging items.
New Document Dialog allows you to create new XML documents, and provide all necessary meta-information for them.
The New Document Dialog appears with the lower part hidden. In the upper part you provide the new document name and the document template
However, if there is no document template for your document type, you can provide these parameters in the lower part of the dialog (click the Details... button).

By choosing the document template in the Template combo you can see that parameters in the lower part are updated. You can modify these parameters that come from the template, and then create the new document.
The Open Document Dialog allows you to easily open XML documents. When opening, Serna tries to guess which stylesheet and schema to use with the document.
If Serna fails to guess, then it brings up the Open Document with Template Dialog (see ), that allows you to explicitly choose the document template and other parameters.

topic.title: Open Document with Template and Document Templates Dialog

section.p: The Document Templates Dialog is called by selecting Document Open with Document Template... and choosing which file to open. The dialog allows you to manually specify what parameters you want to open the document with.
With this dialog you can:

li.b: Open the document with a different encoding
li.p: Just click the Details... button and change the encoding.

li.b: Open the document with metadata specified by one of the existing templates
Open the document with manually specified metadata
li.p: Click on the template category that best fits your document (e.g XHTML ), or click Default if there are none. Then click the Details... button to specify the metadata manually.

section.p: If you create a new document with a document template (see ) that does not prescribe root-elements, then the following dialog shows up after the New Document Dialog:
If the document is opened with Schema validation the text box will show all the available elements in the schema. Select the root element for your new document and click OK.
If the document is opened without Schema validation, then type the root element name in the text box.
However if the document template contains root-elements, then the following dialog shows up:

fig.title: Enter Root Element Dialog with Element Selection

section.p: The Root Element dialog will show only the elements that are both permitted by the schema and listed in root-elements. If you want to start the document from elements that are not in the root-elements list click the "Show All" check-box .
Select the root element for your new document and click OK.

note.p: The Insert Element Dialog is a Liquid Dialog: you can set it as a non-modal, or docked, dialog. To change its appearance right click on the dialog.

section.p: The Insert Element Dialog allows you to insert a new element, or wrap a selection into an element (Tag Region command).

This dialog shows the alphabetically sorted lists of available elements for the current context (when validation is on). It also shows in bold at the top of the list the 5 most recently used elements.
To quickly select an element you may:

li.p: Start typing the element name
Select one from the list
Hit Alt number to pick the corresponding recently used element.

section.p: If you prefer to keep your dialog on top while you edit un-checked, select the Close on insert check box.
The Rename Element Dialog allows you to rename the current element.
This dialog is very similar to the Insert Element Dialog (), except that it is a modal dialog.

note.p: The Element Attributes Dialog is a Liquid Dialog: it may show up as a non-modal dialog, or docked dialog. To change its appearance right click on the dialog.

section.p: The Element Attributes Dialog allows you to insert and edit element attributes. This dialog can be invoked with the Element->Attributes command or Alt Enter . The dialog will show attributes of the element at the current cursor location.
The meaning of icons are as follows:

li.p: This attribute has a default value defined in Schema.
This is a required attribute.
Attribute has a fixed value.
Attribute has ID type.
Attribute has IDREF type.
Attribute has a custom type (Schema data-type).

section.p: Dialog tool buttons are as follows:

li.p: Add new attribute.
Restore default value of an attribute.
Browse for files; relative file name will be inserted as attribute value.
Delete selected attribute.
Invoke Element Help for the currently selected attribute.

section.p: To add a new attribute click (Add) button. If validation is on, the dialog will provide the list of allowed attributes. Choose an attribute from the list or type the attribute name. Click the Value cell to insert/modify attribute values. If the attribute has an enumerated value, clicking on the Value field will provide a list of possible values.
To remove an attribute click on the attribute name cell and click (Delete) button.
To input an existing filename as an attribute value use the (Browse) button.
The Insert Symbol Dialog allows insertion of arbitrary Unicode symbols. These are usually symbols that cannot be entered from the keyboard directly.
To insert a symbol into your document either double click the symbol or click the Insert button.
If the symbol is not visible in the current font (shown at top left), you can change the font.

note.p: The symbol that is visible in the Insert Symbol Dialog may not be visible within the document, because the font in the current position of this document may not contain this symbol. To make the symbol visible correct the font in the stylesheet.

section.p: You can change the shown portion of the Unicode symbols either by typing the character code point into Character Range text-box or by changing the character range combo (middle top).
The arrow buttons next to the Character Range label rewind or fast forward to the adjacent portion of the code table.
You may also compose a list of your favourite symbols with the Ins and Del buttons, or by calling the context menu with a right click.
Insert External Entity Dialog allows insertion of either previously declared entities or XML entities that are not yet declared in the edited document.
To insert a declared external entity simply click on the entity that you wish to insert and click OK.
If the XML entity you wish to insert is not yet declared in the edited file, then:

li.p: Click the Insert From File radio-button.
Type the new entity name in the Entity Name text box.
And type (or browse with the Browse... button) the filename of the entity.
Click OK.

section.p: If the entity is parsed OK it will be automatically declared and inserted into the current position of the document.

Convert to External Entity Dialog allows you to convert a selected document portion to a new external entity. To call this dialog make a selection in the document and click Entity->Convert to External Entity .

Insert the new entity name and new file name (or Browse... to choose a file). Click OK. If an entity with the same name does not already exist, a new external entity will be created from the selected document portion.

note.p: To convert the document portion back from an external entity use the Convert from Entity command ( Entity Convert from Entity).

section.p: Insert Internal Entity Dialog allows you to insert a declared internal entity to the current document position.

The left pane of the dialog shows the tree of declared internal entities. The Internal DTD Subset subtree represents internal entities declared in the edited document, while the External DTD Subset shows internal entities declared in the DTD file that is external to the edited document.
From the left pane, select the internal entity that you wish to insert.
The right pane shows the content of the selected entity (in plain text).
Click OK to complete the operation.
Convert to Internal Entity Dialog allows you to convert the selected document portion to an internal entity. To call this dialog make a selection and click Entity->Convert to Internal Entity... .
Type the new entity name and click OK. If an entity with the same name does not already exist, the selected document portion will be converted to an internal entity.

note.p: To convert the document portion back from an internal entity, use: Convert from Entity command: Entity Convert from Entity.

section.p: The Entity Declarations Dialog allows you to change entity declaration attributes (but not content).

Serna understands the $XML_CATALOG_FILES variable, that is expected to contain the list of system XML Catalogs (semicolon-separated for Windows, and colon-separated for Linux and Mac OS X). Note that catalogs that come first override those following.

section.p: This tab specifies the large document folding parameters. When opening a document Serna estimates the length of the document. section.p: This functionality allows you to change the view of your document by changing the top-level XSLT parameters of the stylesheet in use. The set of concrete values of your stylesheet parameters is called XSLT parameter set. You can create new sets and switch between them during editing process.

For example, in the Docbook documents by default you can see gray boxes (draft areas) right below the section titles that allow you to edit the section meta-information. You now can switch off these boxes by changing the active XSLT parameter set. On the toolbar theres a combo-box with inscription Default View . Select Clean in this combo-box to set the alternative XSLT parameter set which removes the draft areas.
Every stylesheet has at least Default View parameter set, that has the values that are set in the stylesheet itself.
There are two options that allow you to switch between the parameter sets for the current document:

li.p: XSLT Parameter Set combo-box on the tool bar
View Stylesheet Parameters sub-menu in main menu.

You can create new XSLT parameter set or modify an existing one. To do this, open XSLT Parameter Set Dialog: View Stylesheet Parameters XSLT Parameter Sets... :

note.p: Note, that not every top-level XSLT parameter is shown in the dialog. In order to be present, it should have se:type extension parameter. See .

section.p: To modify values of existing parameter set choose the name of parameter set in the Property Set combo-box. Then in the XSLT Parameters table chose the parameter you want to modify, and click Edit or double-click the parameter. You will be able to edit the element in the Edit XSLT Parameter Dialog.

note.p: You cannot edit the values of Default View parameter set. This is the set of the parameters that are provided by the stylesheet itself. You can roll back to the Default View any time.

section.p: To create a new parameter set click either New... or Clone... (if you want to create a parameter set similar to the currently chosen). Syntext Serna offers you a unique functionality to customize and tailor the GUI layout to the needs of a particular user or an enterprise. Feel free to arrange the buttons, toolbars, menus, dockable dialogs, etc. the way you like, change the hot keys and replace the icons with your own.

This chapter deals with information about GUI layout customization proper. To learn how to make the customized GUI layout persistent and even apply it to any installation of Serna in the enterprise, see and .

example.p: Suppose you want to change the hot key for the New Document command to Ctrl L .

section.p: Serna GUI Layout is the current layout of the GUI (buttons, menus, short-cuts, location of buttons and dockable dialogs). If you think the GUI needs some customization like changing the location and appearance of the GUI controls or changing the hot keys, you can easily do it.

For example, you can specify your own icons for the Redlining buttons and move the Redlining toolbar to another location. If you do not need the Redlining toolbar at all, you can remove it. Note that the changed layout will be active only for the current document. If you want your changes to be persistent, you must save them (see .).
For instructions on how to customize the GUI layout, see , and .

The Interface Customizer Dialog allows you to visually customize the Serna GUI layout for the current document, for the current template, and for the default views of Serna. To learn more about the views, see .
The Interface Items tree shows the structure of the current GUI layout.

The user can remove, move, and copy the parts of the layout by removing, moving, and copying the items in the Interface Items structure (use Cut , Copy , Paste and Insert Before /After /Into buttons).

The Available Items palette contains the Serna GUI components that may be inserted in the Interface Items structure, and become visible. Every component may be a child only of a specific list of parents (e.g. menu separator cannot be a child of ContentMap), see "Serna GUI Item Reference Guide".
To insert new items from the component palette, use Copy / Paste and Insert Before/After/Into buttons.
Every GUI item has an identifying name and some other properties displayed in the Item Properties pane.

Some GUI items have the action property. The value of the action property is the ID of a Serna command. One may change a GUI item action to change the behaviour of the item when it is activated (e.g. button is clicked, menu item is chosen).
The properties of an action are displayed in the Action Properties pane. Here are the most common of them:

li.p: The ID of the action (corresponds to the value of the action property in the Item Properties pane).
The inscription on the action control.
The icon for the action control.
The tooltip for the action control.
The hot key for the action.
The ID of the called command event.
The "enabled/disabled" state of the action control.
The ability of the action control to switch between alternate ("on/off") states.
The "on/off" state of the action control.

The Serna GUI global icons common to all documents are compiled-in. The plugin-specific icons coming with the distribution are stored in the icons subdirectory within the plugin directory (e.g. DITA-specific icons reside in sernaInstallationPath\plugins\dita\icons).
It is possible to add your own new icons as well as override the compiled-in icons or overwrite the icons coming with the distribution. The possible graphical formats for the icons are: JPG, GIF, BMP, PNG, XBM, XPM, PNM.
In the dialogs wherever the icons are used (e.g. Custom Content Dialog), the list of registered icons is available in a combo-box.
The following rules apply to overriding and adding new icons:
Global icon files must reside in sernaInstallationPath/icons directory. Plugin-specific icon files must reside in the icons subdirectory within the plugin directory (e.g. sernaInstallationPath\plugins\dita\icons).
Icon size must not exceed 20x20 pixels, otherwise the icon will not be shown in the drop-down lists in the dialogs such as the Custom Content Dialog and Interface Customizer Dialog.
The icon file must be named icon-name.ext, where icon-name must be the same as in the icon's value, and ext should be the extension for the icon graphic type (e.g. new_document.png, dita_topic.png)
You can find an icon's value in the Interface Customizer Dialog. Note that global icons common to all documents have <icon-name> values (e.g. new_document, publish_ah), while plugin-specific icons have <plugin-name>:<icon-name> values (e.g. DITA_Py:dita_topic).
If you want to provide the "disabled" type of the icon you must also provide icon-name_disabled.ext icon file.
To learn how to override/overwrite a GUI icon, see or proceed to the quick start example: See example Overriding an Icon.
