topic.title: GUI Layout and Functional Settings (or simply Views)

section.p: GUI Layout and Functional Settings (simply called as View) in Serna is the current layout of the GUI controls (buttons, menus, short-cuts, location of buttons and dockable dialogs), and also the settings of a specific functionality active for the current document. You can customize the view by changing the location and appearance of the GUI controls and adjusting plugin settings, and make it persistent for all documents of a specific type.

For example, if you change the appearance of the Serna view for a Docbook 4.5 document (template level), then this view will be activated whenever you open any Docbook 4.5 document, while in the case of , say, a DITA document this view won't be activated.

The views are stored in/saved to files that have the following extensions:
sui - These files control the view of Serna GUI layout.
scc - These files control the view of the Serna Custom Content toolbar.
xsltp - These files control the view of XSLT Parameter sets.
tpp - These files control the view of the Table plugin.
ahpp - These files control the view of the Antenna House Formatter plugin.
There can be 5 view levels in Serna, 2 original (coming with Serna distribution) , 2 customized by the user, and 1 applied through Enterprise Configuration Settings package:

li.p: There are three original built-in views: Built-in No Document View (when no document is opened), Built-in View (when a document is opened in WYSIWYG mode), Plain-text view (when a document is opened in text mode).
These views are located in the sernaInstallationPath\ui directory in the following form:
EmptyDocument.sui
StructDocument.sui
PlainDocument.sui

The original view that is activated for any document opened with a particular template. These template-specific view files (templatefilename.*) come with the distribution and are stored in the corresponding sernaInstallationPath\plugins\templatename directories.

note.p: These files get overwritten with the same-named template-specific views applied as Enterprise Configuration Settings.

li.p: These no-template views that are applied through Enterprise Configuration Settings Package are activated in two cases: when no document is opened (No Document View) and when a document is opened without a template (Document without Template). When you apply ECS Package with no-template view files (no_template_view.*, no_document_view.sui), they are saved to sernaInstallationPath\ui directory.
The user-customized view that is activated for any document opened with a particular template.
The user-customized views that are activated in two cases: when no document is opened (No Document View) and when a document is opened without a template (Document without Template).

section.p:
If you have customized a view in Serna and wish to make it persistent, you must save the view. Serna automatically determines the view level and saves the view either for the current template or as the no-template view if the document is opened without a template (see ). The user-customized view files are named no_template_view.* and no_document_view.sui for No-Template level, and templatefilename.* for Template level, and they are saved to the c:\Documents and Settings\YOUR_LOGIN\.serna-&serna-version; directory.
The user-customized view file location (for example, c:\Documents and Settings\YOUR_LOGIN\.serna-&serna-version;\dbk42.sui) is given for Windows. For Linux/Mac OS X, it is $HOME/.serna-&serna-version;.

note.p: The views are activated according to a special priority. For details, see .

section.p: For instructions on how to save, restore or delete a view, see .

You can create a customized view for all documents opened with a particular template or for documents opened without a template. Besides, there are some factory built-in views and views coming with the distribution (to learn more about Serna views, see . You should note that every time you start Serna or open a document in Serna, the view to be activated is chosen in order of priority.

For example, if you save some Serna view for a DITA Task document (e.g. c:\Documents and Settings\YOUR_LOGIN\.serna-&serna-version;\oasis-dita-task.sui), it will override the DITA Task template-specific view file coming with the distribution (c:\Program Files\Syntext\Serna-&serna-version;\plugins\dita\oasis-dita-task.sui).
The views are activated according to the following priority rules:
section.b: The document is opened in WYSIWYG mode.

li.p: If the document is opened from the recent files list ( Document -> Open Recent ), the view for this document is restored exactly as it was when closing the document.
Otherwise, if the document is opened with a template:
If there is a template-specific view file in c:\Documents and Settings\YOUR_LOGIN\.serna-&serna-version;, it is activated (Template level).
Otherwise, if there is a template-specific view file in sernaInstallationPath\plugins\templatename, it is activated (Template Original level).
Otherwise, a built-in view in sernaInstallationPath\ui is activated (Built-in level).

Otherwise, if the document is opened without a template:
If there is a no-template view file in c:\Documents and Settings\YOUR_LOGIN\.serna-&serna-version; (for Windows), it is activated (No-Template level).
Otherwise, if there is a no-template view file in sernaInstallationPath\ui, it is activated (No-Template ECS level).
Otherwise, a built-in view in sernaInstallationPath\ui is activated (Built-in level).
If there is a no-document view file in c:\Documents and Settings\YOUR_LOGIN\.serna-&serna-version;, it is activated (No-Template level).
Otherwise, if there is a no-document view file in sernaInstallationPath\ui, it is activated (No-Template ECS level).
Otherwise, a built-in no-document view in sernaInstallationPath\ui is activated (Built-in level).

note.p: View files of different types (.sui, .scc, .xsltp, .tpp, .ahpp) are searched for independently.

section.p:
To save the current view, take the steps:
Go to View -> Save View .
In the Save View Message Box, click Save.
To learn more about the Save View Message Box, see .
If you forgot to save the view and closed the document, you can restore it: go to Document -> Open Recent , select the document to open, and save the view as described above.
To learn how to delete the saved view, see and . To learn how to restore an original view, see .
To learn more about Serna views, see .
The Save View Message Box tells you the saving path and the level for which the user-customized view will be saved (for information about the view levels, see ):

Serna automatically determines the view level and saves the customized view either for the current template or as the no-template view:
Template level. The view will be rendered for any document opened/created with the current template.
No-Template level. The document without template view will be rendered for any document which doesn't have a template-specific view. When no document is opened, you can save the view as the no document view.
To learn how to save the view, see .

When you start Serna or open a document in Serna, the Serna view is always activated according to a special priority (for details, see and ). When a document is opened with a user-customized view, it is possible to activate the original view.

To restore an original view, take the steps:
Go to View -> Restore View .
In the Restore View Message Box, click Restore .
To learn more about the Restore View Message Box, see .
The Restore View Message Box tells you the level to which the view will be restored (for information about the view levels, see ):

The level is determined automatically. A user-customized template-specific view is restored to the original template level if it is available, otherwise to the original built-in level. A user-customized no-template view is restored to the no-template ECS level if it is available, otherwise to the original built-in level:
Template Original level. The template-specific view that comes with the distribution or that was applied as Enterprise Configuration Settings.
Built-in level. The original view built in Serna.
No-Template ECS level. The no-template view that was applied through ECS Package.

When you restore an original view, the corresponding user-customized view files in c:\Documents and Settings\YOUR_LOGIN\.serna-&serna-version; directory (for Windows) or in $HOME/.serna-&serna-version; (for Linux/Mac OS X) are deleted.
To learn how to restore a view, see .

topic.title: How to Delete View Saved for Template

section.p:
To delete a view saved for a template, take the steps:
Go to the c:\Documents and Settings\YOUR_LOGIN\.serna-&serna-version; directory (for Windows) or to $HOME/.serna-&serna-version; (for Linux/Mac OS X).
Delete the files: templatefilename.ahpp, templatefilename.scc, templatefilename.sui, templatefilename.tpp, templatefilename.xsltp.

topic.title: How to Delete View Saved as No-Template

section.p:
To delete a view saved as no-template, take the steps:
Go to the c:\Documents and Settings\YOUR_LOGIN\.serna-&serna-version; directory (for Windows) or to $HOME/.serna-&serna-version; (for Linux/Mac OS X).
Delete the files:
Document without template view files: no_template_view.ahpp, no_template_view.scc, no_template_view.sui, no_template_view.tpp, no_template_view.xsltp.
No document GUI file: no_document_view.sui.

Enterprise Configuration Settings are the settings of the customized Serna view (see ) and XML metadata files (e.g. xml catalogs, stylesheets, schemas - of interest mostly to developers) which can be applied to any Serna installation in an enterprise.

Suppose someone has created buttons on the toolbar and saved the view as template-specific or no-template view. If they create a package with the view files, these settings can be given out to other people in the enterprise and can be be applied to any Serna installation.
Information about how to create a package with Enterprise Configuration Settings is available in .
For instructions on how to apply the already created package with ECS to any Serna installation in a company, see .

topic.title: How to Apply Enterprise Configuration Settings

section.p: The already created Enterprise Configuration Settings (for instructions on how to create ECS Package, see ) can be applied in two ways: during the installation of Serna or after the installation.

topic.title: How to Apply Enterprise Configuration Settings on Installation

section.p:
The ECS can be applied together with the installation of Serna:
Put the sernaConfig package in the same directory as the Serna installer.
Run the installer.
Perform the installation, as described in Installation Guide.
The installer will automatically apply the settings from sernaConfig. The config-template.xml from the sernaConfig directory will replace the one coming in the distribution.
If you wish to discard the configuration parameters that you configured with config-template.xml, copy the backup files config-template-orig.xml and config-template-orig.ent to config-template.xml and config-template.ent thereafter.
If there are users who already used Serna of the very same version on the same computer, they must refresh their configuration settings:
Choose Tools Preferences General tab.
Click Reset to factory settings .

topic.title: How to Apply Enterprise Configuration Settings after Installation

section.p:
If Serna is already installed on your computer, you can apply the ECS from the Serna GUI or through the command line.
How to Apply Enterprise Configuration Settings from GUI
Install Serna and run it.
Go to Tools -> Preferences .
In the Preferences Dialog, select the General tab.
In the Configuration Package/Package directory , enter the path to the configuration package directory (or use the file browser).
Click Configure .
The settings files will be saved to sernaInstallationPath so they will overwrite the same-named files coming with the distribution if there are any.
Restart Serna for the settings to take effect.
Every user of the installation must do the following:
Choose Tools Preferences General tab.
Click Reset to factory settings .
How to Apply Enterprise Configuration Settings from Command Line
Login as administrator (under Windows, and Mac OS X) or root (under Linux).
Run serna2 -i packageDirName or serna -I packagedirName to apply the configuration settings package. The difference is that -i causes the errors to go to the stderr, while -I causes errors to show up in a message box.
Every user of the installation must do the following:
Choose Tools Preferences General tab.
Click Reset to factory settings .
To learn more about the ECS, see .
Serna user interface language can be changed. To switch supported languages:

li.p: Go to "Preferences" dialog and choose "General" tab;
Choose your language using "User interface language" combo box;
Press "Apply" button to actually change interface language.

section.p: The path for the default stylesheet is:
sernaInstallationPath/plugins/syntext/default/default.xsl.
The default stylesheet is a general-purpose stylesheet that allows you to edit an arbitrary XML document. To use this stylesheet open or create documents with Default Template.

note.p: It is recommended to use this stylesheet in Tag mode, because it isn't optimized for full WYSIWYG.
Starting from Serna version 3.0, TOC is replaced with ContentMap (see ). However, you can still use the old TOC by enabling it with the Interface Customizer.

section.p: The TOC stylesheet is not used for document rendering, but helps you to navigate within the document from Serna ContentMap pane (activated with View->Show/Hide ContentMap menu).
When a document is opened with a Document Template that prescribes some TOC stylesheet (see in the Developer's Guide), the stylesheet is applied.

note.p: For example, Docbook Document Templates included in the Serna distribution use a special Docbook TOC stylesheet, located at sernaInstallationPath/plugins/docbook/docbook-xsl-serna/toc.xsl.

section.p: The stylesheet is located at sernaInstallationPath/xml/stylesheets/docbook-xsl-1.68.1.

Docbook is the most popular DTD for technical documentation. The Serna package includes the Docbook XSL Stylesheet, which renders documents as closely as possible to Norman Walsh's Docbook stylesheet.
The Serna Docbook stylesheet is based on the Norman Walsh stylesheet and modified in order to provide convenient WYSIWYG editing and optimal performance for dynamic execution.

It may be parameterized very similarly to Norman Walsh's Stylesheet (see files parameters.xsl and titlepage.templates.xsl, that is generated with titlepage.generator.xsl from titlepage.templates.xml).
